entry.title: How to install TensorFlow 2.2 on Windows 10
entry.content: How to install TensorFlow 2.2 on Windows 10 TensorFlow 2.2 is the latest version for now 1234conda create -n tf_test python # ÂÆâË£ÖÊúÄÊñ∞Áâà Pythonconda activate tf_test # ËøõÂÖ•ÊâÄÂàõÂª∫ÁöÑ tf_test Ëøô‰∏™ËôöÊãüÁéØÂ¢Épip install tensorflow # ÂÆâË£ÖÈÄÇÈÖçÂΩìÂâçËôöÊãüÁéØÂ¢É Python ÁâàÊú¨ÁöÑ TensorFlowpip install cudnn # Ëá™Âä®ÂÆâË£ÖÊúÄÊñ∞ÁöÑ TensorFlow ÈÖçÂ•óÊîØÊåÅÂ∫ì If return grpcio error, please pip install grpcio via proxy If return can not find DLL error, please conda install cudnn

stream API Âíå kotlin.collections ÁöÑ‰∏ÄÁ≥ªÂàóÂ∫ìÂáΩÊï∞ÔºåÊñπ‰æøÂºÄÂèëËÄÖ‰ºòÈõÖ„ÄÅÂø´ÈÄüÂú∞Êìç‰Ωú PHP Êï∞ÁªÑ„ÄÇ- Êèê‰æõ‰∫Ü‰∏∞ÂØåÁöÑ PHP Êï∞ÁªÑÊìç‰ΩúÂáΩÊï∞ÔºåÊúâÂä©‰∫éÊèêÈ´òÂºÄÂèëÊïàÁéáÂíå‰ª£Á†ÅÁöÑÂèØËØªÊÄß- ‰ΩøÁî® C ËØ≠Ë®ÄÂÆûÁé∞ÔºåÊØîÂêåÁ±ª PHP ÂÆûÁé∞ÊÄßËÉΩÊõ¥È´ò- ÂàùÂ≠¶ËÄÖÂèØ‰ª•ÈÄöËøáÈòÖËØªÊ≠§È°πÁõÆ‰ª£Á†ÅÂ∏ÆÂä©Ëá™Â∑±ÂÖ•Èó® PHP Êâ©Â±ïÂºÄÂèë1234567891011121314151617181920$employees = [ ['name' => 'Alice', 'sex' => 'female', 'age' => 35], ['name' => 'Bob', 'sex' => 'male', 'age' => 29], ['name' => 'David', 'sex' => 'male', Collection::init($employees) ->filter(function ($value) { return $value['sex'] == 'male'; }) ->sortedByDescending(function ($value) { return $value['age']; }) ->map(function ($value) { return Introduction to Financial Engineering Second Version
entry.content: Introduction to Financial Engineering P.S. The course begin at 2019-08-30, thank you for your participation! P.S. The course end at 2019-12-20, thank you for your participation again! Attention I have put the slides in Chinese at bottom of this page, please download the pdf if you need! Schedule and Syllabus unless otherwise specified the lectures are Thursday 19:30pm to 21:55pm in the X1318 in the XIPU campus of Southwest JIAOATONG University. This is the syllabus for the August 30 2019 iteration of the course. You can download the book here. You can download the necessary materials about this book from the author‚Äôs homepage. You can download the Errata about this book. The skills for Financial Engineering Programming: Python Math: Calculus, Linear Algebra, Probability Finance: Finance Market Schedule Event Type Date Title Description Lecture 1 Friday August 30 19:30pm to 21:55pm Introduction 1. Should read the article or material about The Lehman Bankruptcy, which you can get from the link in English or link in Chinese. Lecture 2 Friday September 6 19:30pm to 21:55pm Introduction 1. To find futures and options exchange in China. Link1 Link2 2. To find every king of product in these exchanges. Lecture 3 Friday September 13 19:30pm to 21:55pm Futures Markets and Central Counterparties Review the Futures Markets in chapter 2 and concern Central Counterparties Lecture 4 Friday September 20 19:30pm to 21:55pm Hedging Strategies Using Futures Should be familiar with lesson 4 and will tell you some hedge methods. Lecture 5 Friday September 27 19:30pm to 21:55pm Python for Financial engineering Know the python programming for financial engineering, Demo code Lecture 6 Friday October 4 19:30pm to 21:55pm Interest Rates Should be familiar with lesson 4 and know about some financial terminology: Libor, Federal funds rate, Repo rate, Treasury rate, OIS rate Lecture 7 Friday October 11 19:30pm to 21:55pm Determination of Forward and Futures Prices This lesson will teach you how to determine the price of the futures and forward. Lecture 8 Friday October 18 19:30pm to 21:55pm Interest Rate Futures Day count convention, Treasury Bond and Eurodollar Futures. Lecture 9 Friday October25 19:30pm to 21:55pm Swaps This lesson will teach almost all types of swaps Lecture 10 Friday November 1 19:30pm to 21:55pm Securitization and the Credit Crisis of 2007 This lesson will talk about 2007-2009 in financial market Lecture 11 Friday November 8 19:30pm to 21:55pm XVAs This lesson will talk about XVAs and options Lecture 12 Friday November 15 19:30pm to 21:55pm Mechanics of Options Markets Get into the world of Options Lecture 13 Friday November 22 19:30pm to 21:55pm Properties of Stock Options Introduction to the properties of stock options Lecture 14 Friday December 29 19:30pm to 21:55pm Properties of Stock Options Introduction to the properties of stock options Lecture 15 Friday December 6 19:30pm to 21:55pm Trading Strategies Involving Options Introduction to the strategies of options Lecture 16 Friday December 13 19:30pm to 21:55pm Binomial Trees Introduction to the Binomial Trees and Prepare for the exam! Lecture 17 Friday December 20 19:30pm to 21:00pm exam for 90 minutes! we will have 90 mins test in xipu campus X8215 room! Lecture forever Every Friday 19:30pm to 21:55pm Reading material Python for Finance HomeworkThe First Homework Should read the article or material about The Lehman Bankruptcy, which you can get from the link in English or link in Chinese. Write an electronic reports in Chinese about 1000 words to describe The Lehman Bankruptcy event. You should print it with your Name, Student ID and submit it at next time. Click here to download the format of the homework. Mid-term ExamReading MaterialsBaidu, which is not very good for you. So i recommend that Wikipedia to search the information about LTCM, also, you can read the article written by analyst, who is come form Hong Ming Capital. At last but not least, I think this material is very useful. If all above materials are not sufficient for you, you can find the useful information by yourself. Requirement of the FormatClick here to download the format of the homework. The Content of the Mid-term Exam First, you should choose one of the three opinions about LTCM, especially, your opinion is the most important. Second, there are many different ideas about the bankruptcy of LTCM Support the LTCM for that the default of the Treasury bond can not be control The LTCM should take some methods about the risk of the default of Treasury bond The two side the coin Last, you should write the opinion about the bankruptcy of LTCM, the words in this article should more than 1000 words and less than 5000 words in Chinese. Next class at 2019-11-01, you should give me your homework. The Final ExamReading MaterialsI will put some research articles here RequirementWrite an article about FE using empirical method Attachment: Title Click ==Download== to download the pdf file Á¨¨‰∏ÄÁ´†ÔºöÂØºË®Ä Download Á¨¨‰∫åÁ´†ÔºöÊúüË¥ßÂ∏ÇÂú∫ÁöÑËøêË°åÊú∫Âà∂ Download Á¨¨‰∏âÁ´†ÔºöÂà©Áî®ÊúüË¥ßÁöÑÂØπÂÜ≤Á≠ñÁï• Download Á¨¨ÂõõÁ´†ÔºöÂà©Áéá Download Á¨¨‰∫îÁ´†ÔºöËøúÊúüÂíåÊúüË¥ß‰ª∑Ê†ºÁöÑÁ°ÆÂÆö Download Á¨¨ÂÖ≠Á´†ÔºöÂà©ÁéáÊúüË¥ß Download Á¨¨‰∏ÉÁ´†Ôºö‰∫íÊç¢ Download Á¨¨ÂÖ´Á´†ÔºöËØÅÂà∏ÂåñÂíå2007Âπ¥‰ø°Áî®Âç±Êú∫ Download Á¨¨‰πùÁ´†ÔºöÊúüÊùÉÂ∏ÇÂú∫ÁöÑÊú∫Âà∂ Download Á¨¨ÂçÅÁ´†ÔºöËÇ°Á•®ÊúüÊùÉÁöÑÊÄßË¥® Download

q=0.01", "Accept-Encoding": "gzip, deflate", "Accept-Language": "zh-CN,zh;q=0.9,en;q=0.8", "Connection": "keep-alive", "Content-Length": "95", "Content-Type": "application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=UTF-8", "Cookie": "Hm_lvt_508be7db52fd6da009f33b1d6a262bd3=1568385898; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/76.0.3809.132 Safari/537.36", "X-Requested-With": "XMLHttpRequest"}# ÂàùÂßãÂåñ‰∏Ä‰∏™Á©∫ÁöÑÊï∞ÊçÆÊ°Ütemp_df = pd.DataFrame()# ÈÅçÂéÜÈ°µÈù¢Âπ∂‰∏ä‰º†ÂèÇÊï∞Êù•Ëé∑ÂèñÊï∞ÊçÆfor i in range(1, 719): payload = { "regFileName": "", "itemType": "", "startTime": "", "endTime": "", "entityName": "", "leadManager": "", "regPrdtType": "", "page": i, "rows": 20 } r = requests.post(obj_url, data=payload, headers=headers) if r.status_code == 200: # Áä∂ÊÄÅÁ†Å‰∏∫200Â∞±Ë°®Á§∫Ëé∑Âèñ‰∫ÜÊï∞ÊçÆ data_json = r.json() # Êï∞ÊçÆÁ±ªÂûã‰∏∫ json Ê†ºÂºè for item in data_json["rows"]: # ÈÅçÂéÜ json ÁöÑÂÖ∑‰ΩìÊ†ºÂºè # Â∞Ü json Ê†ºÂºèËΩ¨Âåñ‰∏∫Êï∞ÊçÆÂ∫ì temp_df = temp_df.append(pd.DataFrame.from_dict(item, orient='index').T, sort=False)temp_df.reset_index(inplace=True, drop=True) # ÈáçÊñ∞ËÆæÁΩÆÁ¥¢Âºïtemp_df.to_csv(Path('‰Ω†ÁöÑË∑ØÂæÑ') / "bond_data.csv")

entry.title: Introduction to Fixed-Income Treasury
entry.content: Fixed-Income Treasury P.S. The course begin at 2019-08-27, thank you for your participation! Fixed-Income Treasury P.S. The course begin at 2019-08-27, thank you for your participation! Attention Attention: I have put the slides in chinese at bottom of this page, please download the pdf if you need! We will use Âõ∫ÂÆöÊî∂ÁõäËØÅÂà∏-Á¨¨ÂõõÁâà-Á±ªÊâøÊõú as the main book, click here to buy the book Schedule and Syllabus unless otherwise specified the lectures are Thursday 19:30pm to 20:55pm in the X1320 - in the xipu campus of southwest jiaotong university. This is the syllabus for the August 2019 iteration of the course. You can download the book Fixed Income Securities 7th written by Frank J. Fabozzi. You can download the other materials about author from the author‚Äôs homepage. You can download papers wirtten by author here about this book. The skills of FICC Programming: Python Math: Calculus, Linear Algebra, Probability Finance: Finance Market Schedule Event Type Date Title Description Lecture 1 Tuesday August 27 19:30pm to 20:55pm Introduction 1. Conclusion about the Financial Engineering(last semester) 2. Introduction to the recent financial events 3. Introduction to the FICC and course zero Lecture 2 Thursday August 29 19:30pm to 20:55pm Basic Python Programming for beginers 1. Install python and install pandas, numpy, matplotlib, tushare and other package 2. Use virtual environment and PyCharm 3. Introduction an example about FICC using Python Lecture 3 Tuesday September 3 19:30pm to 20:55pm Bond Fundamentals 1. What is a bond 2. International bond market 3. Chinese bond market Lecture 4 Thursday September 5 19:30pm to 20:55pm Data scientist using Python: Pandas 1. Write your first line of code 2. Get the data from API 3. Examples Lecture 5 Tuesday September 10 19:30pm to 20:55pm Bond Market and Bond Trading 1. Types of bond market 2. How to apply for bond 3. Bond rating Lecture 6 Tuesday September 12 19:30pm to 20:55pm Data scientist using Pandas and Tushare 1. Introduction to Pandas 2. Introduction to Tushare 3. Examples: dowload all data from tushare Lecture 7 Thursday September 17 19:30pm to 20:55pm Introduce the bond market and know about the bond market 1. Kings of market types 2. Issue methods of bond Lecture 8 Tuesday September 19 19:30pm to 20:55pm Get the data from the web of website 1. Analysis the website 2. Introduction to the requests 3. Examples: download the data and save it into local place Lecture 9 Tuesday September 24 19:30pm to 20:55pm Learn the price of bond 1. Pricing of bond 2. Basic knowledge Lecture 10 Thursday September 27 19:30pm to 20:55pm Data analysis 1. Basic data process 2. Examples: process the bond data Lecture 13 Tuesday October 8 19:30pm to 20:55pm Update data 1. Basic data process 2. Examples: update the bond data and calculate the corr Lecture 14 Thursday October 10 19:30pm to 20:55pm Data modeling 1. Basic data modeling 2. Examples: linear regression Lecture 15 Tuesday October 15 19:30pm to 20:55pm Update data 1. Basic data process 2. Examples: update the bond data and calculate the corr Lecture 16 Thursday October 17 19:30pm to 20:55pm Review the content we have learned from this class Prepare for the article about FICC HomeworkWaiting The Mid-term Homework Published: 2019-09-19 Content: To describe the 327 bond event in chinese, reference materials are provided here! To download the fundamental bond data from the website and print the code in paper. Give me the paper in the next class. If all above materials are not sufficient for you, you can find the useful information by yourself. Requirement of the FormatMid-term-Format The content of the Mid-term ExamWaiting The Final ExamReading MaterialsI will put some research articles here or in the attachment RequirementWrite an article about FICC market using empirical method! Deadline2019-10-17! entry.title: Python_report
entry.content: 123456789101112131415161718192021222324252627282930313233343536373839404142434445464748495051525354555657585960616263# coding=utf-8# /usr/bin/env python"""Author: Albert Kingdate: 2019/9/15 18:27desc: Ë∞ÉÁî® configparser Ê®°ÂùóÁÆ°ÁêÜÊÇ®ÁöÑ tokenÔºåÈò≤Ê≠¢ÈáçË¶Å‰ø°ÊÅØÂ§ñÊ≥ÑÔºõË∞ÉÁî® pathlib Ê®°ÂùóÁÆ°ÁêÜË∑ØÂæÑÔºõÂà©Áî® f-strings ÁÆ°ÁêÜÂ≠óÁ¨¶‰∏≤ÊõøÊç¢"""from pathlib import Path # Ë∑ØÂæÑÁÆ°ÁêÜÊ®°Âùóimport logging # Êó•ÂøóÁÆ°ÁêÜÊ®°Âùóimport configparser # ÈÖçÁΩÆÁÆ°ÁêÜÊ®°Âùóimport jqdatasdk as jq # ËÅöÂÆΩÊï∞ÊçÆÊé•Âè£import tushare as ts # Tushare Êï∞ÊçÆÊé•Âè£import pandas as pdpd.options.display.max_columns = Nonepd.options.display.max_rows = Nonelogger = logging.getLogger()logger.setLevel(logging.INFO)logFormatter = '%(asctime)s - %(user)s - %(levelname)s - %(message)s'formatter = logging.Formatter(fmt=logFormatter)console = logging.StreamHandler() # ÈÖçÁΩÆÊó•ÂøóËæìÂá∫Âà∞ÊéßÂà∂Âè∞console.setLevel(logging.INFO) # ËÆæÁΩÆËæìÂá∫Âà∞ÊéßÂà∂Âè∞ÁöÑÊúÄ‰ΩéÊó•ÂøóÁ∫ßÂà´console.setFormatter(formatter) # ËÆæÁΩÆÊ†ºÂºèlogger.addHandler(console)handler = logging.FileHandler(Path(r"C:\Users\king\PycharmProjects\rep_process\config") / 'king.log', mode='w') # mode="a", ‰∏∫ËøΩÂä†Êñá‰ª∂; mode="w", ‰∏∫Êì¶Âá∫ÂêéÂÜôÂÖ•Êñá‰ª∂handler.setLevel(logging.INFO)handler.setFormatter(formatter)logger.addHandler(handler)logger.info("Begin record", extra={'user': 'king'})path_ini = Path(r'C:\Users\king\PycharmProjects\rep_process\config\account_info.ini')config = configparser.ConfigParser()config.read(path_ini)jq_username = config['joinquant']['username']jq_password = config['joinquant']['password']jq.auth(jq_username, jq_password)jq.get_all_securities()ts_token = config['tushare']['token']pro = ts.pro_api(ts_token)data = pro.stock_basic(exchange='', list_status='L', fields='ts_code,symbol,name,area,industry,list_date')for item in data['ts_code'][:10]: df = pro.anns(ts_code=item, start_date='20180401', end_date='20190521', year='2019', fields='ts_code,ann_date,ann_type,title,content,pub_time') content_text = df[(df['ann_type'] == "Âπ¥Â∫¶Êä•Âëä") & (df['title'].str.endswith("Êä•Âëä"))]['content'].values[0] with open(Path(r'C:\Users\king\PycharmProjects\rep_process\tushare_data') / f"{item}.txt", 'w', encoding='utf-8') as f: f.write(content_text) logger.info(f"{item} finished", extra={'user': 'king'})my_name = "jindaxiang"logger.info(f"Finished by {my_name.upper()}", extra={"user": "daxiang"})with open(Path(r"C:\Users\king\PycharmProjects\rep_process\config") / "king.log", "r") as f: print(f.read())

entry.title: Python_basic
entry.content: 123456789101112131415161718192021222324252627282930313233343536373839404142434445464748495051525354555657# coding=utf-8# /usr/bin/env python"""Author: Albert Kingdate: 2019/9/15 18:27desc: Ë∞ÉÁî® configparser Ê®°ÂùóÁÆ°ÁêÜÊÇ®ÁöÑ tokenÔºåÈò≤Ê≠¢ÈáçË¶Å‰ø°ÊÅØÂ§ñÊ≥ÑÔºõË∞ÉÁî® pathlib Ê®°ÂùóÁÆ°ÁêÜË∑ØÂæÑÔºõÂà©Áî® f-strings ÁÆ°ÁêÜÂ≠óÁ¨¶‰∏≤ÊõøÊç¢"""from pathlib import Path # Ë∑ØÂæÑÁÆ°ÁêÜÊ®°Âùóimport logging # Êó•ÂøóÁÆ°ÁêÜÊ®°Âùóimport configparser # ÈÖçÁΩÆÁÆ°ÁêÜÊ®°Âùóimport jqdatasdk as jq # ËÅöÂÆΩÊï∞ÊçÆÊé•Âè£import tushare as ts # Tushare Êï∞ÊçÆÊé•Âè£logger = logging.getLogger()logger.setLevel(logging.INFO)logFormatter = '%(asctime)s - %(user)s - %(levelname)s - %(message)s'formatter = logging.Formatter(fmt=logFormatter)console = logging.StreamHandler() # ÈÖçÁΩÆÊó•ÂøóËæìÂá∫Âà∞ÊéßÂà∂Âè∞console.setLevel(logging.INFO) # ËÆæÁΩÆËæìÂá∫Âà∞ÊéßÂà∂Âè∞ÁöÑÊúÄ‰ΩéÊó•ÂøóÁ∫ßÂà´console.setFormatter(formatter) # ËÆæÁΩÆÊ†ºÂºèlogger.addHandler(console)handler = logging.FileHandler('king.log', mode='w') # mode="a", ‰∏∫ËøΩÂä†Êñá‰ª∂; mode="w", ‰∏∫Êì¶Âá∫ÂêéÂÜôÂÖ•Êñá‰ª∂handler.setLevel(logging.INFO)handler.setFormatter(formatter)logger.addHandler(handler)logger.info("Begin record", extra={'user': 'king'})path_ini = Path(r'account_info.ini')config = configparser.ConfigParser()config.read(path_ini)jq_username = config['joinquant']['username']jq_password = config['joinquant']['password']jq.auth(jq_username, jq_password)jq.get_all_securities()ts_token = config['tushare']['token']pro = ts.pro_api(ts_token)data = pro.stock_basic(exchange='', list_status='L', fields='ts_code,symbol,name,area,industry,list_date')for item in data['ts_code'][:10]: temp_df = pro.daily(ts_code=item, start_date='20180701', end_date='20180718') temp_df.to_csv(f'{item}.csv') logger.info(f"{item} finished", extra={'user': 'king'})my_name = "jindaxiang"logger.info(f"Finished by {my_name.upper()}", extra={'user': 'daxiang'})with open('king.log', 'r') as f: print(f.read())

entry.title: ÂÖ≥‰∫éÁßëÂàõÊùøÈóÆÁ≠î
entry.content: ÁßëÂàõÊùøÂºÄÁõò‰∫§ÊòìËøõÂÖ•ÂÄíËÆ°Êó∂ÔºåÊñ∞ÁöÑÂ∏ÇÂú∫„ÄÅÊñ∞ÁöÑÊÉÖÂÜµ„ÄÅÊñ∞ÁöÑËßÑÂàôÔºåÂ¶Ç‰ΩïÁ°Æ‰øùÁßëÂàõÊùøÂπ≥Á®≥ËøêË°åÔºåÊäïËµÑËÄÖÂ¶Ç‰ΩïÊ≠£Á°ÆÂØπÂæÖÔºåÁßëÂàõÊùøÊé®Âá∫ÂàùÊúüÁöÑÊ≥¢Âä®Ôºü Ë¥¢ÁªèÈ¢ëÈÅì‰∫§ÊòìÊó∂Èó¥ Áã¨ÂÆ∂Êé®Âá∫ ÁêÜÊÄßÁúãÂæÖÁßëÂàõÊùø ‰∏äÊµ∑ËØÅÂà∏‰∫§ÊòìÊâÄÂ∏ÇÂú∫ÁõëÂØü‰∫åÈÉ®Ë¥üË¥£‰∫∫ ÊõæÂàö Ê∏ÖÂçéÂ§ßÂ≠¶ÂõΩÂÆ∂ÈáëËûçÁ†îÁ©∂Èô¢ÂâØÈô¢Èïø ÁéãÂ®¥ ‰∏∫ÊÇ®ÊùÉÂ®ÅËß£ËØª ÁßëÂàõÊùøÊñ∞ËÇ°‰∏äÂ∏ÇÂêéÂâç5‰∏™‰∫§ÊòìÊó•‰∏çËÆæÊ∂®Ë∑åÂπÖÈôêÂà∂ÔºåÂú®‰∏äÂ∏Ç5‰∏™‰∫§ÊòìÊó•‰πãÂêéÔºåÂÆûË°å20%ÁöÑÊ∂®Ë∑åÂπÖÈôêÂà∂ÔºåËøôÊ†∑ÁöÑÂà∂Â∫¶ËÆæËÆ°Âá∫‰∫é‰ªÄ‰πàÊ†∑ÁöÑËÄÉËôëÔºü ‰∏äÊµ∑ËØÅÂà∏‰∫§ÊòìÊâÄÂ∏ÇÂú∫ÁõëÂØü‰∫åÈÉ®Ë¥üË¥£‰∫∫ ÊõæÂàöÔºö ÁõÆÂâçAËÇ°Ê∂®Ë∑åÂπÖÈôêÂà∂Â≠òÂú®‰∏âÂ§ßÈóÆÈ¢òÔºå‰∏ÄÊòØÊ∂®Ë∑åÂÅúÁöÑÊó∂ÂÄôÂ∏¶Êù•Á£ÅÂê∏ÊïàÂ∫îÔºõ‰∫åÊòØÊûÅÁ´ØÊÉÖÂÜµ‰∏ãÈÄ†ÊàêÂ∏ÇÂú∫ÊµÅÂä®ÊÄßÁº∫Â§±Ôºõ‰∏âÊòØÂÆö‰ª∑ÊïàÁéá‰Ωé‰∏ã„ÄÇ‰∏∫‰∫ÜËÆ©Â∏ÇÂú∫ÂÖÖÂàÜÂçöÂºàÔºåÂ∞ΩÂø´ËææÂà∞ÂùáË°°‰ª∑Ê†ºÔºå‰∏ä‰∫§ÊâÄÂú®Êñ∞ËÇ°‰∏äÂ∏ÇÂàùÊúüÊîæÂºÄ‰∫ÜÊ∂®Ë∑åÂπÖÈôêÂà∂„ÄÇ ÁßëÂàõÊùø‰πãÊâÄ‰ª•ËÆæÂÆö‰∏∫Ââç‰∫îÊó•‰∏çËÆæÊ∂®Ë∑åÂπÖÈôêÂà∂Ôºå‰∏ªË¶ÅÊòØÂèÇËÄÉÂõΩÈôÖÊàêÁÜüÂ∏ÇÂú∫ÁöÑÊÉÖÂÜµÔºå‰∏ÄËà¨Êñ∞ËÇ°‰∏äÂ∏Ç‰∫îÊó•Âêé‰ª∑Ê†ºÊ≥¢Âä®ËæÉ‰∏∫Âπ≥Á®≥„ÄÇËÄå‰∏îÔºåËÄÉËôëÂà∞Êñ∞ËÇ°È¶ñÊó•ÂÖÖÂàÜÂçöÂºàÁöÑÊÉÖÂÜµ‰∏ãÔºåÂêéÂõõÊó•ÁöÑËøêË°åÊÉÖÂÜµÂèØ‰∏∫‰∏ã‰∏ÄÊ≠•ÊîπÈù©Êèê‰æõÂèÇËÄÉ„ÄÇ ÁßëÂàõÊùøÂú®‰∏äÂ∏Ç‰∫î‰∏™‰∫§ÊòìÊó•‰πãÂêéÂ∞ÜÊ∂®Ë∑åÂπÖÈôêÂà∂ÊîæÂÆΩËá≥20%Ôºå‰∏ªË¶ÅÊòØ‰∏∫‰∫ÜÂáèÂ∞ë‰∫§ÊòìÈòªÂäõÔºåÊèêÂçáÂ∏ÇÂú∫ÂÆö‰ª∑ÊïàÁéá„ÄÇÊåâÂéÜÂè≤Êï∞ÊçÆÊµãÁÆóÔºå20%ÁöÑÊ∂®Ë∑åÂπÖÁõ∏ÊØîÁé∞Ë°åÁöÑAËÇ°10%ÁöÑÊ∂®Ë∑åÂπÖÈôêÂà∂ÔºåÂèØ‰ª•ÂáèÂ∞ëÁ∫¶80%ÁöÑÊ∂®Ë∑åÂÅúÁé∞Ë±°„ÄÇ Ê∏ÖÂçéÂ§ßÂ≠¶ÂõΩÂÆ∂ÈáëËûçÁ†îÁ©∂Èô¢ÂâØÈô¢Èïø ÁéãÂ®¥Ôºö Êñ∞ËÇ°‰∏äÂ∏ÇÁöÑÂâçÊúüÔºåÊòØ‰ªé‚ÄúÂ±ÄÈÉ®ÂùáË°°‚ÄùÂêë‚Äú‰∏ÄËà¨ÂùáË°°‰ª∑Ê†º‚ÄùËøáÁ®ã‰∏≠ÔºåÁî±‰∫éÊäïËµÑËÄÖÂØπËøô‰∏™‰ª∑Ê†ºÁöÑËÆ§ËØÜËøòÂ≠òÂú®ÂàÜÊ≠ßÔºåËøô‰∏™Êó∂Êúü‰ª∑Ê†ºÊ≥¢Âä®Â§ßÊòØÂêÑ‰∏™Â∏ÇÂú∫Ôºå‰πÉËá≥‰ª∑Ê†ºÂèëÁé∞Êú∫Âà∂ËæÉ‰∏∫ÂÆåÂñÑÁöÑÊàêÁÜüÂ∏ÇÂú∫ÈÉΩÂ≠òÂú®ÁöÑÁé∞Ë±°ÔºåÂΩìÊäïËµÑËÄÖÁöÑ‰ª∑Ê†ºËÆ§ËØÜË∂ã‰∫é‰∏ÄËá¥Êó∂Ôºå‰ª∑Ê†ºÁöÑÊ≥¢Âä®‰πüÂ∞±‰ºöË∂ã‰∫éÂπ≥Á®≥„ÄÇ ÊúâÊäïËµÑËÄÖÊãÖÂøÉÔºåÊó¢ÁÑ∂ÁßëÂàõÊùøÊñ∞ËÇ°‰∏äÂ∏ÇÂêéÂâç5‰∏™‰∫§ÊòìÊó•‰∏çËÆæÊ∂®Ë∑åÂπÖÈôêÂà∂ÔºåÈÇ£‰πàÔºåÂú®Êñ∞ËÇ°Ê∂®Ë∑åÂπÖÊîæÂºÄÁöÑÂêåÊó∂ÔºåÂ¶Ç‰ΩïÈÅèÂà∂Â∏ÇÂú∫ËøáÂ∫¶ÊäïÊú∫„ÄÅÂºÇÂ∏∏Ê≥¢Âä®Ôºå‰øùÊåÅÂ∏ÇÂú∫Á®≥ÂÆö„ÄÅ‰øùÊä§ÊäïËµÑËÄÖÂà©ÁõäÔºü ‰∏äÊµ∑ËØÅÂà∏‰∫§ÊòìÊâÄÂ∏ÇÂú∫ÁõëÂØü‰∫åÈÉ®Ë¥üË¥£‰∫∫ ÊõæÂàöÔºö Á°ÆÂÆûÔºåÊñ∞ËÇ°Âú®Ââç‰∫îÊó•‰ª∑Ê†ºÊ∂®Ë∑åÂÆåÂÖ®Áî±Â∏ÇÂú∫ÂÜ≥ÂÆöÔºåÊ∂®Ë∑åÂ§öÂ∞ëÊ≤°ÊúâÈôêÂà∂„ÄÇ‰ΩÜÊòØÔºåÈíàÂØπÂèØËÉΩÂ≠òÂú®ÁöÑËøáÂ∫¶ÊäïÊú∫„ÄÅÂºÇÂ∏∏Ê≥¢Âä®ÁîöËá≥ËÇ°‰ª∑ÊìçÁ∫µË°å‰∏∫Ôºå‰∏ä‰∫§ÊâÄ‰∏ªË¶ÅÊúâ‰∏âÊñπÈù¢ÁöÑÂáÜÂ§áÔºö ‰∏ÄÊòØÂºïÂÖ•‰∫ÜÊäïËµÑËÄÖÈÄÇÂΩìÊÄßÁÆ°ÁêÜÂà∂Â∫¶ÔºåÈÅøÂÖç‰∏çÂêàÊ†ºÊäïËµÑËÄÖË∑üÈ£éÁÇí‰ΩúÔºõ ‰∫åÊòØÂú®ËøûÁª≠Á´û‰ª∑Èò∂ÊÆµÂºïÂÖ•‰ª∑Ê†ºÁî≥Êä•ËåÉÂõ¥ÈôêÂà∂ÔºåÂêåÊó∂ÂÆûË°åÂ∏Ç‰ª∑Áî≥Êä•‰øùÊä§Èôê‰ª∑ÔºåÂπ∂ÂØπÁõò‰∏≠ÂºÇÂ∏∏Ê≥¢Âä®ÂÆûÊñΩ‰∏¥Êó∂ÂÅúÁâåÂà∂Â∫¶Ôºõ ‰∏âÊòØÂÖ¨ÂºÄ‰∫ÜÂºÇÂ∏∏‰∫§ÊòìÁõëÊéßÊ†áÂáÜÔºåÂπ∂Â∞ÜÂú®Êñ∞ËÇ°‰∏äÂ∏ÇÂàùÊúüÂä†Âº∫ÂºÇÂ∏∏‰∫§ÊòìË°å‰∏∫ÁõëÁÆ°„ÄÇ Ê∏ÖÂçéÂ§ßÂ≠¶ÂõΩÂÆ∂ÈáëËûçÁ†îÁ©∂Èô¢ÂâØÈô¢Èïø ÁéãÂ®¥Ôºö Âú®ÁßëÂàõÊùøÊñ∞ËÇ°‰∏äÂ∏ÇÁöÑÂâç‰∫î‰∏™‰∫§ÊòìÊó•Ôºå‰∏çËÆæÊ∂®Ë∑åÂπÖÈôêÂà∂ÔºåÊÑèÂë≥ÁùÄÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûú‰ª∑Ê†ºÈ´ò‰∫éÂÖ¨ÂÖÅ‰ª∑Ê†ºÁöÑÂπÖÂ∫¶ËøáÈ´òÔºåÂ∏ÇÂú∫ÁöÑÂäõÈáèÂ∞±‰ºöËÆ©‰ª∑Ê†ºËøÖÈÄüÂú∞ÂêëÂÖ¨ÂÖÅ‰ª∑Ê†ºÂõûÂΩíÔºåÂ§±Âéª‰∫Ü‚ÄúË∑åÂπÖ‚ÄùÈôêÂà∂ÁöÑ‰øùÊä§ÔºåÁõ≤ÁõÆËøΩÈ´òÁöÑÊäïËµÑËÄÖÂèØËÉΩÊçüÂ§±‰ºöÂæàÂ§ß„ÄÇ ‰∫§ÊòìÊâÄÂ∑≤Áªè‰ΩúÂá∫‰∫ÜÂÆâÊéíÔºåÂú®Êñ∞ËÇ°‰∏äÂ∏ÇÂâç5Êó•ÁöÑÁõò‰∏≠‰∏¥Êó∂ÂÅúÁâåÊú∫Âà∂ÔºåÂç≥Âú®Áõò‰∏≠Êàê‰∫§‰ª∑Ê†ºËæÉÂΩìÊó•ÂºÄÁõò‰ª∑È¶ñÊ¨°‰∏äÊ∂®Êàñ‰∏ãË∑åËææÂà∞30%„ÄÅ60%Êó∂ÔºåÂàÜÂà´ÂÅúÁâå10ÂàÜÈíü„ÄÇËøôÁßç‰∏™ËÇ°Êñ≠Ë∑ØÂô®Êú∫Âà∂ÔºåËÉΩÂ§üÁªô‰∫àÂ∏ÇÂú∫‰∏ÄÊÆµÂÜ∑ÈùôÊúüÔºåÂáèÂ∞ëÈùûÁêÜÊÄßÁÇí‰ΩúÂ§ñÔºåËøòËÉΩÈò≤ËåÉ‚Äú‰πåÈæôÊåá‚ÄùÁ≠âÈîôËØØËÆ¢ÂçïÁ≠â‚ÄúÂô™Èü≥‚ÄùÂä†ÂâßÂ∏ÇÂú∫Ê≥¢Âä®„ÄÇ entry.title: Introduction to Financial Engineering
entry.content: The course had finished at 2018-12-27, thank you for your participation!Introduction to Financial EngineeringAttention: I have put the slides in chinese at bottom of this page, please download the pdf if you need! Schedule and SyllabusUnless otherwise specified the lectures are Thursday 19:30pm to 21:55pm in the X1320 in the xipu campus of southwest jiaotong university. This is the syllabus for the September 2018 iteration of the course.You can download the book of lectures here.You can download the necessary materials about this book from the author‚Äôs homepage.You can download the Errata about this book. The skills of financial engineering: Programming, Math and FinanceSchedule Event Type Date Title Description Lecture 1 Thursday September 6 19:30pm to 21:55pm Introduction 1. Should read the article or material about The Lehman Bankruptcy, which you can get from the link in English or link in Chinese. Lecture 2 Thursday September 13 19:30pm to 21:55pm Introduction 1. Should read the article or material about The Lehman Bankruptcy, which you can get from the link in English or link in Chinese. Lecture 3 Thursday September 20 19:30pm to 21:55pm Futures Markets and Central Counterparties Review the Futures Markets in chapter 2 and concern Central Counterparties Lecture 4 Thursday September 27 19:30pm to 21:55pm Futures Markets and Central Counterparties Review the Futures Markets in chapter 2 and concern Central Counterparties Lecture 5 Thursday September 29 19:30pm to 21:55pm Hedging Strategies Using Futures Should be familar with lesson 4 and will tell you some hedge methods. Lecture 6 Thursday October 11 19:30pm to 21:55pm Interest Rates Should be familar with lesson 5 and know about some financial ternominology: Libor, Federal funds rate, Repo rate, Treasury rate, OIS rate Lecture 7 Thursday October 18 19:30pm to 21:55pm Determination of Forward and Futures Prices This lesson will teach you how to determine the price of the futures and forword. Lecture 8 Thursday October 25 19:30pm to 21:55pm Interest Rate Futures Day count convention, Treasury Bond and Eurodollar Futures. Lecture 9 Thursday November 1 19:30pm to 21:55pm Interest Rate Futures Day count convention, Treasury Bond and Eurodollar Futures. Lecture 10 Thursday November 8 19:30pm to 21:55pm Swaps This lesson will teach almost all types of swaps Lecture 11 Thursday November 15 19:30pm to 21:55pm Swaps This lesson will teach almost all types of swaps Lecture 12 Thursday November 22 19:30pm to 21:55pm Securitization and the Credit Crisis of 2007 This lesson will teach almost all types of swaps Lecture 13 Thursday November 29 19:30pm to 21:55pm Mechanics of Options Markets Get into the world of Options Lecture 14 Thursday December 06 19:30pm to 21:55pm Properties of Stock Options Introduction to the properties of stock options Lecture 15 Thursday December 13 19:30pm to 21:55pm Properties of Stock Options Introduction to the properties of stock options Lecture 16 Thursday December 20 19:30pm to 21:55pm Review the content we have learned from this class Prepare for the last exam Lecture 17 Thursday December 27 19:30pm to 21:00pm Exam exam for 90 minutes Lecture forever Every Thursday 19:30pm to 21:55pm Reading material https://jfds-1252952517.cos.ap-chengdu.myqcloud.com/files/python_for_finance_2.pdf Homework_1Requirement for homework_1 Should read the article or material about The Lehman Bankruptcy, which you can get from the link in English or link in Chinese. Write an electronic reports in chinese about 1000 words to describe The Lehman Bankruptcy event. You should print it with your Name, Student ID and submit it at next time. Click here to download the format of the homework. Mid-term examReading materialsBaidu, which is not very good for you. So i recommand that Wikipedia to search the infomation about LTCM, also, you can read the article written by analyst, who is come form Hong Ming Capital. At last but not least, I think this material is very useful. If all above materials are not sufficient for you, you can find the useful information by yourself. Requirement of the formatClick here to download the format of the homework. The content of the mid-term exam First, you should choose one of the three opinions about LTCM, especially, your opinion is the most important. Second, There are many different ideas about the bankruptcy of LTCM Support the LTCM for that the default of the Treasury bond can not be control The LTCM should take some methods about th risk of the default of Treasury bond The two side the coin You should write the opinion about the bankruptcy of LTCM, the words in this article should more than 1000 words and less than 5000words in Chinese. Next class at 2018-11-01, you should give me your homework. The final examReading materialsWaiting Requirementjust finish the exam by yourself. entry.title: Spider_about_mafengwo
entry.content: IntroductionDuring the National Day Holidays, i did some work for the purpose of writing a repot about Mount Emei scenic area. The first thing i want to do is how to get the information about Mount Emei, when i was browsing websites on internet, Mafengwo come into my eyes. Then i will pay more attention on mafengwo, especially about how to fetch the data of hotels in every scenic area in www.mafengwo.com Step oneFirstly, i will open the chrome broswer and type in the website of our objective. www.mafengwo.com, then click the http://www.mafengwo.cn/mdd/ site, you will see the , our destination is the Mount Emei, so i click the Â≥®ÁúâÂ±±, then we get into http://www.mafengwo.cn/travel-scenic-spot/mafengwo/10143.html, yes, it‚Äôs the website we needed. In the process of fethcing the data, i think that, to fetch the hotel data is the most difficult, so i choose this part to do a favor. You should broswer the http://www.mafengwo.cn/hotel/10143/?sFrom=mdd, and you will find it‚Äôs something interesting there, because the price of hotle is shown on the screen. entry.title: Machine_Learning_day_04
entry.content: Logistic RegressionWhat is logistic RegressionLogistic regression is used for a different class of problems known as classification problems. Here the aim is to predict the group to which the current object under observation belongs to. It gives you a discrete binary outcome between 0 and 1. A simple example would be whether a person will vote or not in upcoming elections. How does it work?Logistic Regression measures the relationship between the dependent variable(our label, what we want to predict) and the one or more independent variables(our features), by estimating probabilities using it‚Äôs underlying logistic function. Making PredictionsThese probabilities must then be transformed into binary values in order to actually make a prediction. This is the task of the logistic function, also called the sigmoid function. This values between 0 and 1 will then be transformed into either 0 or 1 using a threshold classifier. Logistic vs LinearLogistic regression gives you a discrete outcome but linear regression gives a continuous outcome. Sigmoid FunctionThe Sigmoid-Function is an S-shaped curve that can take any real-valued number and map it into a value between the range of 0 and 1, ==but never exactly at those limits==.

entry.title: Machine_Learning_day_03
entry.content: Multiple Linear RegressionMultiple linear regression attempts to model the relationship between two or more features and a response by fitting a linear equation to observed data. The steps to perform multiple linear regression are almost similar to that of simple linear regerssion. The difference lies in the evaluation. You can use it to find out which factor has the highest impact on the predicted output and how different variables relate to the each other. AssumptionsFor a successful regression analysis, it is essential to validate these assumptions. Linearity: The relationship between dependent and independent variables should be Linear. Homoscedasticity(constant varicance) of the errors should be maintained. Multivariate Normality: Multiple regression assumes that the residuals are normally distributed. Lack of Multicollinearity: It is assumed that there is little or no multicollinearity in the data. Multicollinearity occurs when features(or independent variables) are not independent of each other. NoteHaving too many variables could potentially cause our model to become less accurate, especially if certain variables have no effect on the outcome or have a significant effect on other variables. There are various methods to select the appropriate variable like - Forward Selection Backward Elimination Bi-directional Comparision Dummy VariablesUsing categorical data in Multiple Regression Models is a powerful method to include non-numeric data types into a regression model.Categorical data refers to data values which represent categories - data values with a fixed and unordered number of values, for instance, gender(male/female). In a regression model, these values can be reepresented by dummy variables - variables containing values such as 1 or 0 representing the presence or absence of the categorical value. Dummy variable TrapThe Dummy Variable trap is a scenario in which two or more variables are highly correlated; in simple terms, one variable can be predicted from the others. Intuitively, there is a duplicate category: if we dropped the male category it is inherently defined in the female category(zero female value indicate male, and vice-verse).The solution to the dummy variable trap is to drop one of the categorical variables - if there are m number of categories, use $m-1$ in the model, the value left out can be thought of as the reference value. $y=b_{0} + b_{1}x_{1} + b_{2}x_{2} + b_{3}D_{1}$ Preprocess the data Import the Libraries. Import the DataSet. Check for Missing Data. Encode Categorical Data. Make Dummy Variables if necessary and avoid dummy variable trap. Feature Scaling will be taken care by the Library we will use for Simple Linear Regerssion Model. Fitting our model to the training setThis step is exactly the same as for simple linear regression.To fit the dataset into the model we will use ==LinearRegression== class from ==sklearn.linear_model== library. Then we make an object regressor of LinearRegression Class. Now we will fit the regressor object into our dataset using ==fit()== method of LinearRegression Class. Predicting the test resultsNow we will predict the observations from our test set. We will save the output in a vector $Y_{pred}$. To predict the result we use ==predict()== method of LinearRegression Class on the regressor we trained in the previous step.

entry.title: Machine_Learning_day_02
entry.content: Step 1: Importing the required LibrariesThese Two are essential libraries which we will import every time.NumPy is a Library which contains Mathematical functions.Pandas is the library used to import and manage the data sets. Step 2: Importing the Data SetData sets are generally available in .csv format. A CSV file stores tabular data in plain text. Each line of the file is a data record. We use the ==read_csv== mehtod of the pandas library to read a local CSV file as a dataframe. Then we make separate Matrix and Vector of the independent and dependent variables from the dataframe. Step 3: Handling the Missing DataThe data we get is rarely homogeneous. Data can be missing due to various reasons and needs to be handled so that it does not reduce the performance of our machine learning model. We can replace the missing data by the Mean or Median of the entire column. We use ==Imputer== class of ==sklearn.preprocessing== for this task. Step 4: Encoding Categorical DataCategorical data are variables that contain label values rather than numeric vlaues. The number of possible values is often limited to a fixed set. Example values such as ‚ÄúYes‚Äù and ‚ÄúNo‚Äù can not be used in mathematical equations of the model so we need to encode these variables into numbers. To achieve this we import ==LabelEncoder== class from ==sklearn.preprocessing== library Step 5: Splitting the dataset into test set and training setWe make two partitions of dataset one for training the model called training set and other for testing the performance of the trained model called test set. The split is generally 80/20. We import ==train_test_split()== method of ==sklearn.crossvalidation== library. Step 6: Feature ScalingMost of the machine learning algorithms use the Euclidean distance between two data points in their computations, features highly varying in magnitudes, units and range pose problems. High magnitudes features will weigh more in the distance calculations than featurs with low magnitudes. Done by Feature standardization or Z-score normalizaion. ==StandardScalar== of ==sklearn.preprocessing== is imported.

entry.title: Biographical_sketch
entry.content: Lutz KilianBiographical sketch Lutz Kilian, Professor of Economics, received his Ph.D. in Economics from the University of Pennsylvania in 1996 and his M.A. in Development Banking from The American University in 1988. He joined the faculty at Michigan in 1996. Prior to his Ph.D., he worked for the research department of the Inter-American Development Bank in Washington, DC. During 2001-03 he served as an adviser to the European Central Bank in Frankfurt/M., Germany. Professor Kilian has been a research visitor at the Federal Reserve Board, the European Central Bank, and the International Monetary Fund. He has also been a consultant for the International Monetary Fund, the Inter-American Development Bank, the World Trade Organization, the European Central Bank, the Bank of Canada, the European Parliament, and the U.S. Energy Information Administration, among others. Professor Kilian has published over 90 articles. His work has appeared in leading general interest and field journals in economics and statistics. He is the author of a textbook with Helmut L√ºtkepohl on Structural Vector Autoregressive Analysis, Cambridge University Press, 2017. His research interests include time series econometrics, empirical macroeconomics, and energy economics. Much of his recent research is concerned with the sources of fluctuations in the price of oil, with the transmission of oil price shocks, with the role of speculation in oil markets, with measuring oil price expectations in financial markets, and with oil price forecasting. He has also published on topics in empirical macroeconomics and in international finance including the stagflation of the 1970s, the specification of monetary policy rules, the quantification of deflation risks, the role of sticky prices in business cycle models, and tests of exchange rate models. Finally, he has worked extensively on topics in time series econometrics with a special focus on bootstrap methods of inference for autoregressions, on impulse response analysis, on the estimation of structural parameters in DSGE models, on the specification and identification of structural VAR models, on forecasting and forecast scenarios, and on testing predictability. Professor Kilian has served as an Associate Editor for the Journal of Business and Economic Statistics, the Journal of Development Economics, and the Journal of Economic Dynamics and Control, among other journals. He is a research fellow of the Centre for Economic Policy Analysis, the Center for Financial Studies, the CESifo, and the Euro Area Business Cycle Network. Curriculum VitaeCurriculum Vitae TextbookPreliminary chapters of textbook on ‚ÄòStructural Vector Autoregression Analysis‚Äô(with Helmut Lutkepohl) Research List of published and forthcoming papers Links to selected papers, data sets, and code Links to selected blog and press articles on speculation in oil markets and related topics Course Syllabi Syllabus for Economics 495 (Applied Time Series Analysis) Syllabus for Economics 457 (Financial Econometrics) Syllabus for Economics 671 (Econometrics I) Syllabus for Economics 676 (Macroeconometrics) Data links Economic Time Series Webpage St. Louis Fed: FRED Bureau of Economic Analysis Bureau of Labor Statistics Michigan Survey of Consumers Philadelphia Fed: Real Time Data Set, somethings error from the page NBER Data IFS 404 error OECD 404 error OECD: Main Economic Indicators 404 error Eurostat European Central Bank U.K. National Statistics Stock returns University of Michigan Documents Center University of Michigan data bases More data links ‚Ä¶ Lutz Kilian E-mail: lkilian@umich.edu Department of Economics University of Michigan Ann Arbor, MI 48109-1220 Phone: (734) 647-5612 FAX: (734) 764-2769 Last Updated: February 6, 2017

MacOS High Sierra-10.13.5 install win10
entry.content: MacOS High Sierra-10.13.5 install win10 Configuration MacBook Pro(13-inch, 2017, Four Thunderbolt 3 Ports) Edition: 10.13.5 Processor: 3.5 GHz Intel Core i7 Memory: 16GB 2133 MHz LPDDR3 Graphics card: Intel Iris Plus Graphics 650 1536 MB Sequence to open the MacBook Pro Set the password and AppID, input fingerprint Be careful that choose the SYSTEM PREFERENCE and get into the Secure and Privacy item and stop the file safe. Go to MSDN to download the Win10(click the website to find which version you will want) and save the file in the MacBook Pro Go into Launchpad and choose folder named other, choose the Boot Camp and click the next item Wait for seconds, you will enter the item named install windows, you can choose the ISO images item, the next you choose the APFS container, at this time, you may choose the divide the SSD into half, and the click the install item The IOS will download the necessary files from the web of the APPLE, if it had an error, you just try again, this process will need 5 minutes, according to your speed of the internet, just waiting. When item 6 finished, the computer will restart, then we go to install win, just follow the steps in normal. When the computer appear the windows, we should open the c:/OSXRESERVED/BootCamp/, and click the install install item, and waiting for the process Restart the computer, it will get into the win system, a dos window will appear, please wait for seconds At last, you will continue to install the necessary softwares in the computer. For example, Anaconda for win, Office for win, Notepad++, QQpinyin and so on.
